author: @roachsinai6716
text: Thanks for this great series! And anyone download the `bg.txt` from the web link provided by @sentdex, and using Linux, maybe should check the file by `vi` not `vim` to see is there a `^M` at the end of each line, and remove it to avoid the ERROR: invalid fastbin entry (free) [1]    29831 abort (core dumped)  opencv_createsamples.

author: @Casowsky
text: Just a question, in the part where we remove the 'uglies', why not use a np.bitwise_and(x,y).all() operation as opposed to the np.bitwise_xor(x,y).any()?  Both seem to produce the same result (as far as I've tested with a folder of images and the Flickr 'file not found' image), and to me it seems to make a bit more sense logically. You're testing to see whether or not all the pixels in image A are the same as pixels in image B (because you want to remove those) and you can do that by 'anding' them with each other.  Just wondering if there's something I'm missing or if there are certain situations where that breaks or produces incorrect results. Loving the series by the way - you have an awesome 'line by line' teaching style and great production on all your videos!

author: @shenqiangshou
text: If you only have access to a shell and don't want to bother viewing the pre-de'uglied' file list to find a 'ugly', you can always do a ls -lS|tail, basically sort by size ascending and show last 10.  Any actual image will be fairly large, but most of the 'uglies' will be the exactly the same, and tiny, size. Like 973 bytes or something.

author: @TurkishLoserInc
text: OK, so for python 2.7 and opencv 3.1 ( the tutorial to download on ubuntu 16.04 is here: http://www.pyimagesearch.com/2016/10/24/ubuntu-16-04-how-to-install-opencv/ You might need a fix when opencv doesn't compile: https://github.com/opencv/opencv/issues/6016  After following those steps, we fall at these tutorials. As we are on python 2.7, both the previous version and this file have some small changes that need to be made, which can be found here: https://github.com/UltharPeliki7/oduasv2017/blob/master/haarurl.py If you have any questions, I welcome them below.
